translatedsentence1: Ke idem mi, n̄kpaha n̄kpọ ndomokiet emi n̄kopde bụt, nte n̄kụtde nte ẹkedụkde mi. Enyịn esie ama ofụhọ, onyụn̄ osio idem efep ke enyịn esie emi ekedide akpanikọ.

sentence1: And maybe it won't.  Slow and mocking came Wolverstone's voice to answer the other's confident excitement, and as he spoke he advanced to Blood's side, an unexpected ally.
translatedsentence1: Ndien ekeme ndikabade ntreke. Sia-sia ye nsu-nsu ke uyo Wolverstone ama otoho ndibok idatesit owo enwen emi okonyung enyene mbufo, ndien nte enye okodohode, enye ama asanade ekpere Blood, owo emi owo mma mmeneke idaha ke enye edinyene.

sentence1: You were just an unfortunate gentleman then.
translatedsentence1: Afo ekedi owo emi mînyeneke mfọn ke ini oro.

sentence1: Captain Blood bared his head and bowed silently in a greeting which she returned composedly and formally.
translatedsentence1: Captain Blood ọkpọri ibuot esie onyụn̄ etie ke idak idak ke nsụhọde ibuot ke edisọk emi enye n̄ko osọkde ke emem ye ke usụn̄ usụn̄.

sentence1: There had been trouble with Bishop from the moment of landing.
translatedsentence1: Ekekop afia ye Bishop toto ke ini enye akasanade ikodu.

sentence1: Meanwhile Ogle was growing impatient.
translatedsentence1: Ke adan̄a oro, Ogle akana esie ubak.

sentence1: Lord Julian was sententious, as I gather that he often was.
translatedsentence1: Ọbọn̄ Julian ekedi owo ikọ, nte n̄kụtde ke enye ekesidi ntre.

sentence1: Aye--a deal of lies, devil a doubt, as I could prove to you.
translatedsentence1: Ih--ediwak ikọ ikịk, idem ke ndudue idụhe, nte n̄kpọkọfiọk ndiwụt fi.

sentence1: But I was in haste to land you.
translatedsentence1: Edi mma-enyene iyara ndida fi ke isọn̄.

sentence1: You should have seen the danger.
translatedsentence1: Afo ekpenyene ndikụt ubiere oro.

sentence1: I realize fully what you did, and I realize that partly, at least, you may have been urged by consideration for myself.
translatedsentence1: Mmenim ke ofụri ofụri se afo akanamde, ndien mmenim nte ke ubak, esisịt, afo ekeme ndida n̄kpọ n̄kere mi.

sentence1: I'll not be detaining you any longer, ma'am.
translatedsentence1: Ndidaha fi aba, ma.

sentence1: It's our only chance....   The rest of his words were drowned in the shouts of the hands insisting that the girl be given up to be held as a hostage.
translatedsentence1: Enye edi ikpọn̄ ikpọn̄ ifet nnyịn.... Ndien mme ikọ eken esie ẹma ẹdịp ke otu uyom mbon oro ẹkedoride ke enyịn ẹte ẹnọ eyen an̄wan oro ẹkama nte n̄kpọ n̄kpọkọbi.

sentence1: That is not in the bargain.
translatedsentence1: Oro idịghe ke n̄kpọ oro ikọdọhọde.

sentence1: He observed her pale and tense, with parted lips and startled eyes that were fixed upon him, an anxious witness of this deciding of her fate.
translatedsentence1: Enye okụt enye ke mbubru-mbubru ye ọkpọsọn̄ idaha, ye inua esie emi okopde ye enyịn esie emi ẹkpaidemede emi ẹkọn̄ọde enye, nte ntiense emi enyenede akwa udọn̄esịt ke ubiere uduak esie.

sentence1: And she shivered at the memory of it.
translatedsentence1: Ndien enye okpokpo idem ke nditi enye.

sentence1: Aye!  roared in chorus the buccaneers below, and one or two of them elaborated that affirmation.
translatedsentence1: Aaa! mbon buccaneer oro ẹkedoro ke idak ẹbiere ikop, ndien owo kiet m̀mê iba ke otu mmọ ẹkenam ikọ oro an̄wan̄a.

sentence1: In the cabin he flung into a chair, and exploded, with a violence altogether foreign to his nature.
translatedsentence1: Ke ufok, enye ama odụk ke n̄kpọsịbe ye odudu, ndien enye ama etop ke iyatesịt, ye idiọk odudu oro mîdịghe ke edu esie n̄kaha.

sentence1: I killed him, it is true.
translatedsentence1: Mmawot enye, edi akpanikọ.

sentence1: Captain,  he said, and as he spoke he pointed to the pursuing ships,  Colonel Bishop holds us.
translatedsentence1: Captain, enye ọdọhọ, ndien nte enye etịn̄de, enye owụt ubom oro ẹdịkde mmọ, Colonel Bishop emen nnyịn.

sentence1: That'll cool Colonel Bishop's heat, maybe.
translatedsentence1: Oro eyen̄wan̄a iyatesịt Bishop Colonel, ekeme ndidi.

sentence1: Your station is on the gun-deck.
translatedsentence1: Ebiet udak-utom fo edi ke okpokoro ubom ekpo.

sentence1: So I heard,  she admitted in a small voice.
translatedsentence1: Ntre ke n̄kop, enye ọkọnyịme ke n̄kpri uyo.

sentence1: But laugh though he might, he knew as well as Pitt that in going ashore that morning he carried his life in his hands.
translatedsentence1: Edi kpa ye kpukpru esen̄e oro, enye ama ọfiọk nte Pitt nte ke ndika ikpaesịt uwemeyo oro enye ekeda uwem esie ke ubọk esie.

sentence1: I... I had not dreamed....
translatedsentence1: N̄kaha ndap.

sentence1: But there is no hope for him in that!  she cried.
translatedsentence1: Edi baba idotenyin iduho inye ke oro! ekere.

sentence1: I will take leave to doubt it.  His lordship's tone abated nothing of its asperity.
translatedsentence1: Nyemede ndiduek enye. Uyo Obon esie ikpuhoho ke uto esie.

sentence1: There was here quite plainly a vague threat, a mutinous spirit he could not understand.
translatedsentence1: Ake do ke akpanikana n̄kpọndịk kiet oro mîdịghe akpan akpan, ye spirit unana-ndinyịme oro enye mîkemeke ndifiọk.

sentence1: Don't be forgetting that.   Jeremy clenched his hands.
translatedsentence1: Kûfreke oro. Jeremy okpono ubok esie.

sentence1: But it gave no pause to the gunner's intention.
translatedsentence1: Edi ikpaha idaha ke uduak owo ubom.

sentence1: But Blood's mind was now made up.
translatedsentence1: Edi ifiọk Blood ama akabade ọsọn̄.

sentence1: Why, as I was just telling his lordship here, who thought like you that having Miss Bishop aboard would make us safe, not for his mother would that filthy slaver forgo what's due to him.
translatedsentence1: Nso, kpa nte n̄kedade n̄kọdọhọ edidem emi, emi ekekere nte afo ke ndinyene Miss Bishop ke ubom ayanam nnyịn ikpeme idem, idịghe ke ntak eka esie ke ndek owo ntan̄a oro idifọn̄ke se enye enyenede.

sentence1: In his cabin on the starboard side Lord Julian, disturbed by the same sounds, was already astir and hurriedly dressing.
translatedsentence1: Ke ubet esie ke ufan ubok nnasia, Lord Julian, emi ikpuhede ke ikpo ukpo, ama osioho ke idap onyung osioho eyenowo ke nso.

sentence1: Let me present Captain Blood.   Perforce Bishop must put on the best face he could command.
translatedsentence1: Yak n̄wet Captain Blood. Edi Bishop ama ana anyan̄a idem ye iso oro enye ekemede ndida.

sentence1: Pitt, at his post beside the helmsman, turned intrepidly to face the excited gunner.
translatedsentence1: Pitt, ke ebiet esie ke n̄kan̄ owo oro ekpemede ubom, okabade enyịn ye uko ndida iso ye owo oro ekwọrọde nsak-nsak ibom.

sentence1: Blood leaned over the rail to speak to the fair young man immediately below him by the helmsman at the whipstaff.
translatedsentence1: Blood ekpep ke enyọn̄ ikpa ubọk ubom ndineme ikọ ye akparawa oro enyene-mbara oro okodude ke idak esie ke ntịn̄ntịn̄, enyịn̄ akpama ubom ke ubọk ubọk ubom.

sentence1: The country is all, sir; the sovereign naught.
translatedsentence1: Idụt edi kpukpru, ete; emi akara edi ikpîkî.

sentence1: His hand closed over the butt of one of the pistols slung before him.
translatedsentence1: Ubọk esie ama okịbi ke ikpa ubọk kiet ke otu n̄kpọ-ekọn̄ emi ẹkọbọde ke iso esie.

sentence1: It gives him a grievance at last.
translatedsentence1: Enye anam enye enyene ibak ke akpatre.

sentence1: Wait!  Blood bade him, interrupting, and he set a restraining hand upon the gunner's arm.
translatedsentence1: Tie! Blood okot enye, onyung abiat enye, ndien enye onyung ada ubok esie okop enye ke ubok owo emi okama ubok-ekpo.

sentence1: And for all that he lost nothing of his outward stern composure, fear invaded his heart.
translatedsentence1: Ndien kpa ye kpukpru oro, enye ikpaha baba n̄kpọ kiet ke idaha esie eke an̄wa emi okowụtde ke imọ iduho ke n̄kpọntịbe, edi ndịk ama odụk enye esịt.

sentence1: Through her and through you.
translatedsentence1: Ke enye ye ke afo.

sentence1: Though we had a cargo of Bishop's nieces it wouldn't make him hold his hand.
translatedsentence1: Kpa ye nte ke ikenyene ediwak nditọeka Bishop, emi ikedịghe n̄kpọ ndinam enye etre.

sentence1: If now he can show that....
translatedsentence1: Edieke idahaemi enye ekeme ndiwụt ke....

sentence1: That is what we were advised.
translatedsentence1: Oro ke ẹkenam nnyịn item.

sentence1: How?  she asked him with a sudden startled interest.
translatedsentence1: Didie? ebụp enye ye ikan̄ikan̄ udori esịt emi okopde n̄kpaidem.

sentence1: ‘Twill be a kindness, so it will.   For a moment she stood before him with quickened breathing, the colour ebbing and flowing in her cheeks.
translatedsentence1: Enye eyedi ima, ntre ke edi. Ke esisịt ini enye akadaha ke iso esie ye odudu emi ọsọsọpde, ntịn̄enyịn̄ ke enye ke ebịne onyụn̄ ọkpọn̄ ke ikpọkidem esie.

sentence1: He was moved to raise his voice above its usual languid level.
translatedsentence1: Ekemede enye ndikop uyo n̄kan usụn̄ emi enye esikopde uyo ke ndobo ndobo.

sentence1: My name is Wade--Lord Julian Wade.
translatedsentence1: Enyịn̄ mi edi Wade--Lord Julian Wade.

sentence1: I see, sir, that you do not yet quite apprehend the circumstances.
translatedsentence1: Mmokụt, ete, ke afo ufiopke kan̄a idaha oro.

sentence1: I am pressed,  she informed him.
translatedsentence1: Mmekpa, enye eketịn̄ ọnọ enye.

sentence1: As for me,  said Lord Julian, with intent to make Miss Bishop's departure free from all interference on the part of the buccaneers,  I shall remain aboard the Arabella until we reach Port Royal.
translatedsentence1: Ke n̄kan̄ ami, Lord Julian ọkọdọhọ, ye uduak ndinam Miss Bishop efep ke ukpọn̄ kpukpru n̄kpọsịbe ke ubọk mme buccaneer, nyen̄wọn̄ọ ndidu ke Arabella tutu isịm Port Royal.

sentence1: Then:   You ordered it?  he said in accents of unbelief, whilst Lord Julian raised his eyebrows.
translatedsentence1: Ndien: Afo eketoro enye? enye ọkọdọhọ ke usụn̄ unyenịm, ke adan̄aemi Lord Julian okodori enyịn esie.

sentence1: Expressly.   His lordship waited a moment for a reply.
translatedsentence1: Ke akpanikọ. Ọbọn̄ esie ebet ekpri ini ndibọrọ.

sentence1: You know, Peter, that it is Lord Julian alone has stood between Bishop and his hate of you.
translatedsentence1: Afo ọfiọk, Peter, ke edi Lord Julian ikpọn̄ emi adade ke ufọt Bishop ye usua esie fo.

sentence1: But many could not resolve one way or the other until they were satisfied upon several questions, and chiefly upon one which was voiced by Ogle.
translatedsentence1: Edi ediwak owo ikemeke ndibiere kiet m̀mê efen tutu mmọ ẹkop inemesịt ke mme mbụme oro, akpan akpan ke kiet emi Ogle eketịn̄de.

sentence1: Ye're going to deliver yourself into Bishop's hands,  Pitt warned him.
translatedsentence1: Afo ubon ke unam fi nnọ Bishop, Pitt ọdọhọ enye.

sentence1: Standing beside Captain Blood, he looked astern, following the indication of the Captain's hand, and cried out in his amazement.
translatedsentence1: Eda ke n̄kan̄ Captain Blood, enye ese edem ubom, etiene se ubok Captain owụtde, onyụn̄ ofiori ke n̄kpaidem esie.

sentence1: He may be right, and he may be wrong.
translatedsentence1: Ekeme ndidi enye enen, ndien ekeme ndidi enye inenke.

sentence1: But if she resented his tone and his words, she stifled her resentment.
translatedsentence1: Edi edieke enye akasuade ikọ ye uyo esie, enye ama okpụhọde isua esie.

sentence1: I am informed that yesterday evening a frigate left the harbour having on board your associate Wolverstone and a hundred men of the hundred and fifty that were serving under you.
translatedsentence1: Ẹdọhọ mi ke uwemeyo eyo, ubom ekọn̄ kiet ọkpọn̄ ebiet ubom, ye ufan fo Wolverstone ye ikpọ owo ikie ke otu ikpọ owo ikie ye edịp oro ẹkedụn̄de ke idak fo.

sentence1: And instantly would have recalled the words had she been able.
translatedsentence1: Ndien ke mbuari ekpeketi ikọ oro edieke enye ekpekekeme.

sentence1: But that it was no more than a mask for his fury and his venom was plain to all.
translatedsentence1: Edi ke ikedịghe se ikenen̄ede ibe ikpọk idaha ke ntak iyatesịt ye obube esie, emi eketie an̄wan̄wa kpukpru owo.

sentence1: Levasseur?  He smiled a little.
translatedsentence1: Levasseur? Enye ama-inyene nsek-enyene.

sentence1: HOSTILITIES   In the great harbour of Port Royal, spacious enough to have given moorings to all the ships of all the navies of the world, the Arabella rode at anchor.
translatedsentence1: EKỌN. Ke akwa ebiet idaha ubom ke Port Royal, emi okpondeke ndinọ ebiet idaha kpukpru ubom ekọn kpukpru idụt ke ererimbot, Arabella okodaha ke ebiet idaha.

sentence1: He swung to Lord Julian.
translatedsentence1: Enye ekpep ebe Lord Julian.

sentence1: Good-morning to you,  he said, and added  I've blundered badly, so I have.
translatedsentence1: Mma eti usen, etịn̄, onyụn̄ adian do nte, Mmekop ndudue akwa akwa, ntre ke edi.

sentence1: He stepped back, a baffled, impotent man.
translatedsentence1: Enye amafiak edem, owo emi esịt etịmede, emi mînyeneke odudu.

sentence1: Although even some o' they should know better, for there's still a few was on Barbados with us, and are acquainted like me and you with Colonel Bishop.
translatedsentence1: Kpa ye oro, ndusụk mmọ ẹkpakam ẹfiọk n̄kpọ ẹkan, koro ndusụk mmọ ẹkesụk ẹdu ye nnyịn ke Barbados, ẹnyụn̄ ẹfiọk Colonel Bishop kpa nte ami ye afo ifiọkde.

sentence1: Pitt, loosely clad in shirt and breeches, leaned against the rail the while and watched him, unmistakable concern imprinted on his fair, frank countenance.
translatedsentence1: Pitt, emi ekesịne ikpọho ọfọn̄ ye kpukpru n̄kpọ, ama esịne ke n̄kpọ n̄kpọkọbi onyụn̄ ese enye, ndien n̄kpọ eke etie nte n̄kpọ enye enen̄ede ekere ama owụt ke iso esie eke enye mîdịghe owo ukwan̄ikọ.

sentence1: That'll be the signal to lie to,  said Blood, in the same listless voice; and he fetched a sigh.
translatedsentence1: Oro eyedi idiọn̄ọ ndisu nsu, Blood ọdọhọ, ke ukem uyo oro mînyeneke odudu; ndien enye esịn edịbe.

sentence1: And what better are these?--Are ye afeard of a lubberly Barbados planter? Whatever ails you, Peter? I've never known ye scared afore.   A gun boomed out behind them.
translatedsentence1: Ndien nso ke mmọ ẹfọn ẹkan emi? Ndi ndịk anam mbufo owo in̄wan̄ Barbados emi mîfiọkke n̄kpọ? Nso ke anam fi, Peter? N̄kwe fi ndịk anam kpukpru ini. Ikpaukot ekọn̄ okop etop ke edem mmọ.

sentence1: And a couple of miles this side of it, bearing after them, came speeding three great white ships.
translatedsentence1: Ndien ke ikpe ufan iba ke edem emi, ẹtiene mmọ, ubom ikpọ ifia ifia ita ẹsọp ẹdi.

sentence1: It's our only chance, I've said, and we must take it.   The better way that was in Captain Blood's mind was the way that already he had proposed to Wolverstone.
translatedsentence1: Afo edi ikpọn̄ ikpọn̄ ifet nnyịn, mmọdọhọ, ndien ana nnyịn inam. Akwa usụn̄ emi ekedide ke ekikere Captain Blood ekedi usụn̄ emi enye ama okpọn̄ etịn̄ ọnọ Wolverstone.

sentence1: The young master's grey eyes skimmed it.
translatedsentence1: Enyịn ebu akparawa ete okụt enye ke usọp usọp.

sentence1: Whether the men in the panic Ogle had aroused among them would take a different view from Wolverstone's he did not know.
translatedsentence1: Mme ire mboniren ke ubaha emi Ogle akanamde odoro mmọ ẹyeda ekikere efen ẹkpụhọde ye eke Wolverstone, enye ikọfiọkke.

sentence1: Heave her to, and signal to them to send a boat.   A silence of astonishment fell upon the ship--of astonishment and suspicion at this sudden yielding.
translatedsentence1: Daha ubom oro, ndien nọ mmọ idiọn̄ọ ẹdọn̄ ubom. Ufịk uyo n̄kpaidem ama ọduọk ke ubom--n̄kpaidem ye n̄kpọsọn̄ ekikere ke ntak emi mmọ ẹkedehe ke mbuari.

sentence1: I accept it as the only way to save us all from the certain destruction into which my own act may have brought us.
translatedsentence1: Mmenịme ke enye edi usụn̄ kiet kpọt ndinyan̄a nnyịn kpukpru nsio ke akpan nsobo emi utom mi ekemede ndida nnyịn ndu.

sentence1: I... I can't think why you should speak to me like this,  she said, with less than her earlier assurance.
translatedsentence1: N... N̄kemeke ndikere ntak emi afo ekpenyenede nditịn̄ ikọ nnọ mi ntem, enye ọkọdọhọ, ye unyịme oro mîkan̄wan̄ake nte ekedide ke ntọn̄ọ.

sentence1: And the quixotic fool is running into danger at the present moment on our behalf.
translatedsentence1: Ndien owo mfina oro ke efehe odụk ke n̄kpọndịk idahaemi ke ibuot nnyịn.

sentence1: A thin, sour smile broke on the officer's haughty lips.
translatedsentence1: Unyịme-enyịme asari amafiak ke edịbe ọfis emi akpade ikpọ.

sentence1: So that ye can be charitable in some ways!  He laughed softly.
translatedsentence1: Man mbufo ekeme ndidi mbon ima ke ndusụk usụn̄! Enye ama an̄wan̄a n̄kpri n̄kpri.

sentence1: Hark to the gentleman!  he mocked.
translatedsentence1: Nkop owo oro! Enye akpakpa.

sentence1: Threats will not serve, Captain.
translatedsentence1: Ubiat-ibuot idinyeneke ufọn, Etubom.

sentence1: Captain Blood's glance raked the ranks of those resolute, fierce-eyed fellows, then it came to rest again on Ogle.
translatedsentence1: Enyịn Captain Blood okodụk otu mbon oro ẹkekopde odudu, mbon enyịn ikpọk, ekem enyịn esie okodu ke Ogle.

sentence1: If ye're counting on pulling Bishop's heartstrings, ye're a bigger fool, Ogle, than I've always thought you was with anything but guns.
translatedsentence1: Edieke afo etiede ke ndibiet Bishop esit, afo edi akwa ndisisi akan, Ogle, akan nte mmesikere ke afo edi ke n̄kpọ ekededi ke adianade do ye uto ke ikpọn̄.

sentence1: He had found the only way, and repellent though it might be to him, he must take it.
translatedsentence1: Enye ama okụt usụn̄ kiet kpọt, ndien kpa ye oro enye mîkopke inemesịt aban̄a, ana enye ada.

sentence1: He threw them at me again and again.
translatedsentence1: Enye okpono mmọ ọnọ mi utịm ikaba.

sentence1: That is: that he has been notified of the coming of Lord Julian Wade.
translatedsentence1: Oro edi: ke ẹmenede enye etop mban̄a edidi Obong Julian Wade.

sentence1: Oh, please.  There was real alarm in her voice.
translatedsentence1: Ami, mbọk. Akpanik n̄kpọndịk okodu ke uyo esie.

sentence1: Fearing to betray the latter, she took refuge in the former.
translatedsentence1: Ke ndikop ndịk ndiyak enye emi ekedide akpatre, enye ekedịbe ke enye emi ekedide akpa.

sentence1: You take that tone! You dare to take that tone!  she cried, astounding him by her sudden vehemence.
translatedsentence1: Afo ada uyo oro! Afo amama ndida uyo oro!

sentence1: You may have heard of me.   Captain Calverley stared hard.
translatedsentence1: Afo ekeme ndikop mban̄a mi. Captain Calverley okụt enyịn etieti.

sentence1: It isn't that.   But they were fated to misunderstand each other.
translatedsentence1: Idịghe oro. Edi ẹkewetde mmọ ndikere n̄kpọ ke ndudue ye kiet eken.

sentence1: If anything should happen to you, Peter,  he said, as Blood was going over the side,  Colonel Bishop had better look to himself.
translatedsentence1: Edieke n̄kpọ ndomokiet etịbede fi, Peter, enye ọkọdọhọ, nte Blood okosụk edede ke n̄kan̄, Colonel Bishop ekpenyene ndise mban̄a idemesie.

sentence1: I'll be getting my hat and cane and sword, and go ashore in the cock-boat.
translatedsentence1: Nyeda akpanikpa-ibuot mi, ye eto-ukot, ye ofiom, nnyon ke ison ke ekpri ubom.

sentence1: I must return to Colonel Bishop for my orders,  he informed them.
translatedsentence1: Nnyene ndifiak n̄ka ke Colonel Bishop mban̄a odudu mi, etịn̄ ọnọ mmọ.

sentence1: In a flash Captain Blood saw what was in their minds.
translatedsentence1: Ke usen kiet, Captain Blood okụt se ikodude ke ekikere mmọ.

sentence1: I do my best,  said she.
translatedsentence1: Nnam se n̄kemede, enye ama ọdọhọ.

sentence1: Oh, but--by your leave--surely there is nothing to be apprehended from Colonel Bishop.
translatedsentence1: A-a, edi--ke unyịme fo--akpanikọ ke baba n̄kpọ ndikop ndịkke ito Colonel Bishop.

sentence1: I wonder, now,  he said presently,  if the mischief is of your working.
translatedsentence1: Nsinam n̄kere, ke emi, enye ọdọhọ ke ndondo emi, m̀mê idiọkn̄kpọ oro edi utom fo.

sentence1: Shrewd advocacy,  he approved it.
translatedsentence1: Udomo ndin̄wam ke ifiọk, enye enyịme.

sentence1: I have something to show you.   Wondering, Lord Julian mounted the companion as he was bidden.
translatedsentence1: Mmenyene n̄kpọ ndiwak fi. Ke n̄kpaidem, Lord Julian ama adaha aka enyọn̄ ubọk nte ẹkedoride enye.

sentence1: Before we've run another half-mile we shall be within range.   Wolverstone swore elaborately, then suddenly checked.
translatedsentence1: Mbemiso ikopde ubak-mile enwen, iyedu ke n̄kpọsọn̄. Wolverstone ekekpe ikọ ke usụn̄ oro, ekem osio idem ke mbuari.

sentence1: He's chivalrous to the point of idiocy.
translatedsentence1: Enye enyene eti edu ye uko tutu esịm ndisịme.

sentence1: He levelled his telescope upon that figure.
translatedsentence1: Enye ama ọdọn̄ telescope esie ke mbiet oro.

sentence1: Miss Bishop was aboard the Royal Mary also, and I rescued her together with his lordship.
translatedsentence1: Miss Bishop n̄ko okodu ke ubom Royal Mary, ndien mma nnyan̄a enye ye andinyene enye.

sentence1: What if he can?  Blood interrupted carelessly.
translatedsentence1: Nso edieke enye akeme? Blood ọkọbiọn̄ọ ke ikpọk-ikpọk.

sentence1: I'll rot in hell or ever I serves the King,  he bawled in a great rage.
translatedsentence1: Nyekpu ke hell mbem iso nnam n̄kpọ nnọ Edidem, enye ọkọkọm ke akwa iyatesịt.

sentence1: Ye're surely daft even to think of it, Peter!
translatedsentence1: Afo edi odomo odomo ndikere mban̄a, Peter!

sentence1: Standing now at the rail, with Lord Julian beside him, Captain Blood explained himself.
translatedsentence1: Eyeneka etie idahaemi ke ubom, ye Obong Julian ke nkan̄ esie, Captain Blood ama anam an̄wan̄a idemesie.

sentence1: A boat that had approached unnoticed from the shore came scraping and bumping against the great red hull of the Arabella, and a raucous voice sent up a hailing shout.
translatedsentence1: Ubom kiet emi okosopde ke n̄kan̄ ke usụn̄ emi owo mîkwe, ama edisọp onyụn̄ okop ikpọk ikpọk ye n̄kpọk n̄kpọk ke akwa ikpa ubom Arabella emi esụn̄de, ndien uyo kiet emi okodude ke n̄kpọk n̄kpọk ama osio uyo ikot.

sentence1: Ye'll remember afterwards that it was your hardness drove me.   She moved to depart, then checked, and faced him again.
translatedsentence1: Afo ayeti ke ini iso ke isen esịt fo ekedi emi ekedomode mi. Enye ama adaha ndika, ekem enye ama adaha ke idaha, onyụn̄ ese enye ke iso ikaba.

sentence1: Faith, you explain yourself after a fashion,  said he.
translatedsentence1: Faith, afo anam anwan̄a idem fo ke usụn̄ kiet, enye eketịn̄.

sentence1: A drinker of blood, he is.
translatedsentence1: Enye edi on̄wọn̄ iyịp.

sentence1: It's the truth, you fool.
translatedsentence1: Akanam akpanikọ, afo ndisịme.

sentence1: Heave to, Captain, and signal them to send a boat, and assure themselves that Miss is here.
translatedsentence1: Daha ke n̄kan̄, Captain, nyụn̄ nọ mmọ idiọn̄ọ ẹsio ubom ẹdi, man mmọ ẹkụt ke Miss odu mi.

sentence1: And if ye' weren't a fool, Ogle, you wouldn't need me to tell you this.
translatedsentence1: Ndien edieke afo mûkponke odomo, Ogle, afo ikpenyenedeke mi nditịn̄ nnọ fi emi.

sentence1: And what should be happening to me, Jeremy? Sure, now, I'll be back for dinner, so I will.   Blood climbed down into the waiting boat.
translatedsentence1: Ndien nso ke akpana etịbe mi, Jeremy? Ke akpanikọ, idahaemi, nyọnyọñ edi udia, ntre nyọnyọñ. Ema okonyịbe osụk odụk ke ubom emi ekedorode enyịn.

sentence1: Just within the doorway of the alley leading to the cabin, he ran into Miss Bishop.
translatedsentence1: Ke usung ufuk usung nsan nsan usung oro adade aka ufok, enye okokop Miss Bishop.

sentence1: Ogle,  said he, in a voice cold and sharp as steel,  your station is on the gun-deck.
translatedsentence1: Ogle, etịn̄de, ke uyo emi ọkpọde ye ọsọn̄de nte ukwak, ebiet fo edi ke enyọn̄ ubom utịm.

sentence1: Yet she had not been coming out, for her back was towards him, and she was moving in the same direction.
translatedsentence1: Nte ededi, enye ikamaha ndiwọrọ, koro edem esie okodu enye, ndien enye okodu ke ukpep kiet.

sentence1: The museum is not strong on catalogues or labels
translatedsentence1: Ufok nkaiferi oro inyeneke ndutịbe n̄kpọ m̀mê ndutịbe enyịn̄ n̄kpọ eke ọfọnde.

sentence1: You can see beluga whales in summer, polar bears in the autumn, and, if you're around at the spring or autumn equinox, the  northern lights  of the aurora borealis.
translatedsentence1: Ẹkeme ndikụt akwa n̄kpọkịkịm inyan̄ ke ini ofụm, edịbe ikpọk ke ini uduak, ye, edieke afo odude ke ini ukem-enyọn̄ ini edịm m̀mê ini uduak, un̄wana edere.

sentence1: Canal Motorboats BV has two locations in the city
translatedsentence1: Canal Motorboats BV enyene ebiet iba ke obio

sentence1: These open-air markets are also the most interesting places to shop in Beijing.
translatedsentence1: Mme urua obukpọn̄ emi ẹdi n̄ko mme ebiet emi ẹnen̄ede ẹdori owo esịt ndida n̄kpọ n̄kpọp ke Beijing.

sentence1: Linked to Nova Scotia by the narrow Chignecto Isthmus, New Brunswick became a separate province in 1784 at the demand of 14,000 Loyalist refugees.
translatedsentence1: Ekebe ke Nova Scotia ke akpa Chignecto Isthmus, New Brunswick akabade obio-ukara ke 1784 ke ntak uduak owo 14,000 emi ekedide mbon Loyalist emi ekefehede.

sentence1: The largest bay on the northwest coast makes a fine harbor, but both the water and the beach can be dirty.
translatedsentence1: Akamba inyan̄ ke n̄kpọkịta edere-enyọn̄ anam eti ebiet idaha ubom, edi mmọn̄ ye esụk ẹkeme ndidi ikpafak.

sentence1: Those skyscrapers are banks, and the street on which they stand has been nicknamed the Milla de Oro, or Golden Mile.
translatedsentence1: Mme akamba ufọk oro ẹdi ufọk-mbubehe okụk, ndien usụn̄ emi mmọ ẹdade ke enyọn̄ esie ẹkpe enyịn̄ 'Milla de Oro,' m̀mê 'Golden Mile.'

sentence1: Children will enjoy the Cite de la Mer (37 Rue de l'Asile Thomas), with exhibits on the history of boatbuilding, the fishing industry, and how tides and currents shape the coastline.
translatedsentence1: Nditọwọn̄ ẹyema Cite de la Mer (37 Rue de l'Asile Thomas), ye mme n̄kpọ ndụn̄ọde aban̄a mbụk edibọp ubom, ufọk-utom ukọiyak, ye nte mmọn̄ inyan̄a ye mmọn̄ oro ẹsan̄ade ẹkpụhọrede mbenesụk.

sentence1: Natural enough, then, that involvement in World War II began with a British Commonwealth Air Training Plan, using Canada's safer skies to prepare pilots for combat.
translatedsentence1: Ke ntre, enen̄ede edi se inende ke ndidụk ke Akwa Ekọn̄ Ererimbot II ọkọtọn̄ọ ye British Commonwealth Air Training Plan, ẹda ikpaenyọn̄ Canada emi enyenede nsọn̄idem ndikpep mme andiwat ubomofụm ndin̄wana ekọn̄.

sentence1: The Ming Tombs were once a staple of tours to the Great Wall at Badaling, but foreign tourists have seldom been impressed by the site, finding it dank and poorly restored.
translatedsentence1: Mme Udiñ Ming ẹkedi akpan ebiet ke isan̄ ndika Akwa Obukpo ke Badaling, edi mme isen isan̄a-isan̄ ikekwe n̄kpọ ndidara ke ebiet oro, ẹkụt ke enye enyene ndo ye ke ẹma ẹfiak ẹnam enye ke usụn̄ emi mîfọnke.

sentence1: The best ports in the Mediterranean are June, July, August, and Mae,  said the 16th-century Venetian admiral Andrea Doria, noting that beyond the summer sailing season, a fleet couldn't do better than shelter here.
translatedsentence1: Mme ebiet usung ubom eke ofon akan ke Inyan̄ Mediterranean edi June, July, August, ye Mae, Andrea Doria, adiaha ubom eke Venice eke ọyọhọ isua ikie 16, ọkọdọhọ, ndien etịn̄ ke ke adianade ye ini usung ubom eke ini ufiop, ikpọ ubom ikemeke ndinyene ebiet eke ofon akan ndidịp idem ke do.

sentence1: Among the 27 hiking trails the best are the Glasgow Lakes trail to John Deer Lake and the trail around Beulach Ban Falls and French Mountain.
translatedsentence1: Ke otu usụn ikpọkiso 27, mme usụn eke ẹfọnde ẹkan edi usụn Glasgow Lakes osịm John Deer Lake ye usụn eke okụrede Beulach Ban Falls ye French Mountain.

sentence1: And they remain tolerant and helpful, even though they know that their lovely coast is no longer just theirs.
translatedsentence1: Ndien mmọ ẹka iso ndinyene ime ye ndin̄wam, kpa ye oro mmọ ẹfiọkde ke mbeninyan̄ mmọ oro ẹdụn̄de ke enyịn idịghe eke mmọ ikpọn̄ aba.

sentence1: Kublai Khan erected his own capital in 1279 on the shores of Beijing's Beihai Lake, where some of his imperial treasures remain on display today.
translatedsentence1: Kublai Khan ama anam obio ibuot esie ke isua 1279 ke mben Inyan̄ Beihai ke Beijing, emi ndusụk inyene ubọn̄ esie osụk ẹdu ke n̄kpọ ndise mfịn.

sentence1: The roadless Na Pali Coast on the heavenly north shore is one of the world's most challenging and majestic seaside hikes (see page 71).
translatedsentence1: Na Pali Coast oro mînyeneke usụn̄ ke edem edere eke heaven edi kiet ke otu akpan isan̄ ikpa inyan̄ eke ererimbot oro ọkpọsọn̄de onyụn̄ enyenede ubọn̄ (se page 71).

sentence1: Assimilating more easily with the Anglo community only Protestant schools accepted their children Eastern European Jews have  graduated  to wealthy Westmount or emigrated, again, to Toronto.
translatedsentence1: Mme Jew eke Eastern Europe, emi ẹkedianade ye mbon Anglo ke usụn̄ eke ọsọn̄ke, ndien mme ufọkn̄wed Protestant kpọt ẹkenyịme nditọ mmọ, ẹma ẹdọk ẹka Westmount eke inyene m̀mê ẹkpọn̄ obio, n̄ko, ẹka Toronto.

sentence1: If possible, familiarize yourself with the plot in advance.
translatedsentence1: Edieke ekeme, diọn̄ọ mbụk oro mbemiso.

sentence1: His burial vaults, 27 m (88 ft) below ground, are made of marble and cover 1,200 sq m (13,000 sq ft).
translatedsentence1: Mme udi esie, mita 27 (ukot 88) ke idak isọn̄, ẹnam ke okuta marble ẹnyụn̄ ẹdaha mita square 1,200 (ukot square 13,000).

sentence1: Napoleon attacked and destroyed Catalonia's sacred shrine, the monastery at Montserrat.
translatedsentence1: Napoleon ekeduan̄a onyụn̄ esobo edisana ebiet utuakibuot Catalonia, ufọkabasi mme mọnk ke Montserrat.

sentence1: Remember to hide all portable possessions from the monkeys.
translatedsentence1: Ti ndibre kpukpru n̄kpọ eke ẹkemede ndida n̄ka ke enan̄.

sentence1: Some 1,400 years before the Palace of Estei was erected, Milreu was also the large country house of an eminent person.
translatedsentence1: N̄kpọ n̄kpọ isua 1,400 mbemiso ẹkebọp Akwa Ufọk Estei, Milreu n̄ko ekedi akwa ufọk obio-ikọt owo akwa-owo.

sentence1: With its entry into the Common Market in 1981, Greece's economic prospects strengthened.
translatedsentence1: Ke ini Greece okodukde Common Market ke 1981, idotenyin inyene esie okosop.

sentence1: Sea temperatures vary between 18e and 24e C (64-75e F).
translatedsentence1: Ukpomoyoyo inyan̄a esio ke otu degree 18 ye degree 24 Celsius (degree 64 ye degree 75 Fahrenheit).

sentence1: The Kinabalu national park is just one of six protected regions in the state.
translatedsentence1: Kinabalu national park edi kiet ke otu itie ekpepde ikot eke isua eke ke obio.

sentence1: Sofias, next to the Megaro Mousikis Metro station.
translatedsentence1: Sofias, ekpere ufok-mbok Megaro Mousikis Metro.

sentence1: To the east of the gate is the Olympieion, site of the largest temple ever built on Greek soil.
translatedsentence1: Ke usoputịn enyịnyịme do edi Olympieion, ebiet emi akwa ufọkabasi oro ẹkenịmde ke isọn̄ Greece.

sentence1: The Poble Espanyol (Spanish Village), on Montjuac's northeastern flank, is an attraction for which the cliche  fun for the whole family  might have been invented.
translatedsentence1: Poble Espanyol (Obio Ufok Spanish), ke n̄kan̄ edere edem usiahautin Montjuac, edi ebiet emi mme owo ẹsinyene inemesịt, emi ikọ oro “inemesịt ọnọ ofụri ubon” ekeme ndidi ẹkebotde ẹnọ.

sentence1: Today the old building hosts the Edinburgh Experience, a 20-minute, 3-D slide show charting the history of the city and bringing to life the Edinburgh of today (April-October only).
translatedsentence1: Mfịn, akwa ufọk oro esịne Edinburgh Experience, kpa ndise slide 3-D eke minit 20, oro etịn̄de aban̄a mbụk obio oro onyụn̄ anamde Edinburgh eke mfịn odu uwem (ke April tutu October kpọt).

sentence1: Dora Stratou Folk Dance Theater presents performances of traditional Greek song, dance, and music at a traditional  folk-village -type auditorium on Philopappos Hill from May to September daily except Mondays.
translatedsentence1: Dora Stratou Folk Dance Theater ọnọ ndinam ikwọ, ubọk-edomo ye ikwọ-ikwọ Greek eke eset ke ufọk-ndise nte obio-eset ke Obot Philopappos toto May esịm September kpukpru usen, ke adianade do Monday.

sentence1: You'll see videos of Anne's story and of Amsterdam under occupation along with photographs and artifacts of the time.
translatedsentence1: Afo ayeda vidio aban mbuk Anne ye aban Amsterdam ke idak ukara, ye ndise ye n̄kpọ eke ini oro.

sentence1: Beside it, the Norman Gothic La Martorana church, partly remodeled with a Baroque faaade and porch, has a fine campanile with four storys of slender mullioned windows.
translatedsentence1: Enyịn̄ esie, ufọkabasi La Martorana emi ẹkebọpde ke usụn̄ Norman Gothic, emi ẹkewọrọde ẹdiọn̄ ubak ke iso ye itie-ukpọn̄ ke usụn̄ Baroque, enyene eti tọwa ikwọrọde emi enyenede edịbe inan̄ ye n̄kpri window emi ẹnyenede n̄kpọ-ukpọn̄ ke ufọt.

sentence1: The lake itself lies in the shadow of several high mountains, including Scafell Pike, the highest in England at 977 m (3,205 ft).
translatedsentence1: Enyọn̄ mmọn̄ oro ke idemesie ododu ke idak ediwak ikpọ obot, esịnede Scafell Pike, emi edide akamba obot ke England ke mita 977 (ukot 3,205).

sentence1: This collection of European and Puerto Rican art, probably the finest in the Caribbean, would be very much at home in any European capital.
translatedsentence1: Nneme ndise Europe ye Puerto Rico emi, emi ekeme ndidi edi se ifonke ifon akan ke Caribbean, eyedi n̄kpọ emi mîkpaha mba ke ibuot obio Europe ekededi.

sentence1: Treasure Beach is the only resort area to speak of, with just a handful of hotels stretching across three sandy bays.
translatedsentence1: Treasure Beach edi ikpọn̄ ebiet udia-idem oro owo ekemede nditịn̄ mban̄a, ye n̄kpri ufọk-edia-idem ifan̄ kpọt oro ẹkpande inyọn̄ inyan̄ ita eke ntan.

sentence1: Then comes Bona, a center of basketry which also bills itself as the home of the kecak dance.
translatedsentence1: Ekem edi Bona, akpan ebiet ubọp ekpat, emi enye n̄ko okotde idem esie nte ufọk ekọn̄ kecak.

sentence1: If you're feeling up to it, push on along the Mist Trail, past Emerald Pool, to Nevada Fall, and you'll begin to lose the crowds.
translatedsentence1: Edieke idem enyene fi, ka iso ke usung Obukpo, ebede Inyang Esmeralda, sika Idịm Nevada, ndien afo uyom ndikpuho mme owo.

sentence1: Summer brings warm (but not hot) weather and warm sea temperatures, making it ideal for diving, snorkeling, and other water sports.
translatedsentence1: Ini uyo ada enyong ofiom-ofiom ye ukpom mmong inyan̄ ofiom-ofiom, emi anamde enye edi se ifon̄de etieti ye ndibok mmong, ndise n̄kpọ ke idak mmong, ye mme utọ n̄kpọ nduọkodudu eken ke mmong.

sentence1: Among the ponds is one inhabited by  Visitors toss in coins in the hope of bouncing one off a turtle's head, a sure way of achieving good fortune.
translatedsentence1: Ke otu mme inuen mmọn̄, owo kiet ododu emi mbe ẹdụn̄de ke esịt. Mme isenowo ẹsịnde okụk ke idotenyịn ndida kiet n̄kọk ke ibuot mbe, kpa usụn̄ ndinyene eti uforo.

sentence1: Among the many jazz clubs are the famed Jazz Bakery in Culver City, the Catalina Bar and Grill in Hollywood, and the Baked Potato in North Hollywood.
translatedsentence1: Ke otu ediwak ufok jazz, edi Jazz Bakery emi enyenede eti enyịn̄ ke Culver City, Catalina Bar and Grill ke Hollywood, ye Baked Potato ke North Hollywood.

sentence1: At the center of the resort, in the sheltered waters of the inner lagoon, there is a  Swim with the Dolphins  program.
translatedsentence1: Ke ufọt ebiet udiafọn, ke mmọn̄ eke ẹkpeme ke esịt inua-mmọn̄, edi edinam 'Ubre ye Nnụn̄-mmọn̄' do.

sentence1: The port town of Nafplio makes the perfect base for touring the area, or perhaps a spot to have lunch while on your tour.
translatedsentence1: Obio inyan̄a Nafplio edi akpan n̄kpọ ndida n̄kpep n̄kpọ m̀mê ndika n̄kpere n̄kpọ ke ikpehe oro, m̀mê ekeme ndidi ebiet ndidia udia uwemeyo ke ini afo odude ke isan̄ fo.

sentence1: Some of its residents are descendants of the valiant laborers who helped build the Canadian Pacific Railway.
translatedsentence1: Ndusụk mbonidụn̄ esie ẹdi nditọ nditọ mbonutom oro ẹken̄wamde ẹbọp Canadian Pacific Railway.

sentence1: Get off at the stop before Batthyany ter to admire the colourful exterior of the 1896 Neo-Gothic Calvinist Church which features in so many panoramas of the city.
translatedsentence1: Sana ke ebiet udun emi odude ke iso Batthyany ter man enyebe mbang ye nsio-nsio uduot ke anade ke Ufok Abasi Calvinist emi ẹkebọpde ke ukpepn̄kpọ Neo-Gothic ke isua 1896, emi esidude ke ediwak ndise obio.

sentence1: It was here in 1775 that 100 barrels of gunpowder mysteriously disappeared from stores in Fort St. Catherine and found their way onto a boat bound for the use of the American revolutionaries.
translatedsentence1: Ke ebiet emi ke isua 1775, ikpọk 100 eke n̄kpọsọbọ ẹma ẹbiat ke n̄kpọsọn̄ usụn̄ ke ufọk n̄kpọuto ke Fort St. Catherine, ndien mmọ ẹma ẹkụt usụn̄ ẹdụk ubom emi ekekade ndin̄wam mbon America emi ẹkekọbọde ukara.

sentence1: Others well worth visiting include the home of Balzac (47 Rue Rayanouard) and Delacroix's studio (6 Rue de Furstenberg).
translatedsentence1: Mbon en̄wen eke ẹdotde ndise esịn ufọk Balzac (N̄kpọ 47 Rue Rayanouard) ye ufọkutom Delacroix (N̄kpọ 6 Rue de Furstenberg).

sentence1: In Prinsengracht, Otto Frank and his family hid in the attic of their business premises for over two years before being discovered.
translatedsentence1: Ke Prinsengracht, Otto Frank ye ubon esie ekedịbe ke enyọn̄ ufọk ufọk utom mmọ ke ofụri isua iba ye n̄kpọ mbemiso ẹkụtde mmọ.

sentence1: If you've become an adept of the tea ceremony, you'll appreciate the excellent collection of 14th-century  ceramic tea bowls, tea kettles, and caddies, as well as bamboo spoons, whisks, and flower vases.
translatedsentence1: Edieke afo akabarede owo oro enyenede ifiọk ke usụn̄ unam tii, afo ayama akwa n̄kpọ emi ẹkụtde ke n̄kpọkọbi tii eke ọyọhọ isua 14, itiat tii, ye n̄kpọkọbi tii, kpasuk nte ikpọk tii eke eto, ye n̄kpọ unam tii, ye n̄kpọkọbi ikọn̄.

sentence1: The showpieces are the new lion exhibit, snow leopard and cheetah exhibits, and an African tropical rain forest, which is complete with gorillas and warthogs.
translatedsentence1: Mme akpan n̄kpọ eke ẹwụtde ẹdi ebiet idaha obufa ekpe, ye ebiet idaha ekpe ikpọk ye ekpe n̄kpọsọn̄, ye akai edịbe mmọn̄ Africa emi enyenede gorilla ye ebi.

sentence1: Even the location of the building is a technological marvel.
translatedsentence1: Ata ebiet ufok oro odude edi n̄kpọ utịbe ke n̄kpọntịbe.

sentence1: In fact, it was the flashpoint for protests and riots during the busing controversy in the 1970s.
translatedsentence1: Ke akpanikọ, enye ekedi ebiet emi mbume ye afai ẹketọn̄ọde ke ini ikpe ubọk-ubọk ke mme isua 1970.

sentence1: Famous for its August log-rolling contests, the town of Squamish makes a useful base for hiking tours into Garibaldi Provincial Park.
translatedsentence1: Obio Squamish, oro enyenede eti enyịn ke ntak mbre ukpọk eto ke August, edi eti itie nditọn̄ọ isan̄ ukwọrọde ke Garibaldi Provincial Park.

sentence1: For an authentic feel of old Portugal, slip into the cool entrance hall of theimpressive Leal Senado ( Loyal Senate  building), a fine example of colonial architecture.
translatedsentence1: Man afo ekop nte Portugal akasanade ke eset, duop ke esop iduok odudu ke enyene-ndobo ufok Leal Senado (ufok-ibon Eyen-Obio), kpa eti uwutnwed ufok-ibon mme andikara.

sentence1: (The event is repeated on 14-15 August. )
translatedsentence1: N̄kpọntịbe oro ẹnam en̄wen ke usen 14 ye 15 August.

sentence1: Dominating the mouth of Sant Antoni Bay is the gaunt silhouette of the island of Coniera, or Conejera (meaning  rabbit's warren  or  burrow ).
translatedsentence1: Enye akara inua Sant Antoni Bay edi idịbi isọn̄ Coniera, m̀mê Conejera, emi etiede nte n̄kpọ emi ọkpọsọn̄de, (emi ọwọrọde 'ufọk ibiom' m̀mê 'obube').

sentence1: These link the main public beaches (from Warwick Long Bay to Horseshoe Bay).
translatedsentence1: Mmọ ẹdiana mme akpan in̄wan̄ inyan̄ eke owo (ọtọn̄ọde ke Warwick Long Bay esịm Horseshoe Bay).

sentence1: During the Sixth Crusade (1228- 1229), the Holy Roman Emperor Frederick II managed to secure Jerusalem for the Christians by negotiation.
translatedsentence1: Ke ini Akparawa Ifiok Itiaba (1228-1229), Edidem Frederick II eke Obio Ukpono Rome ama okop uforo ndida Jerusalem nnọ mme Christian ke ndineme nneme.

sentence1: Forming part of the city wall, the gate was intended by the more pragmatic Prussians not so much as a triumphal arch as an imposing tollgate for collecting duties.
translatedsentence1: Nte ubak ke ibibene obio, inuaotop oro, mme Prussian emi ekedide mbon ifiok ye utom ikereke enye nte inuaotop edara, edi nte akwa inuaotop utoho ndibọ utoho.

sentence1: Apart from the set pieces, most of the music is percussive and serves to support and reflect the action and mood.
translatedsentence1: Ke adianade ye mme ikwọ oro ẹkenịmde ke edem, ediwak ikwọ ẹdị ikwọ eke ẹkụbọde, ndien mmọ ẹsinam utom ndin̄wam ye ndiwụt se isitịbede ye nte owo etiede ke idem.

sentence1: The pattern repeated itself a century later when the Moors invoked the aid of the Almohads in 1151.
translatedsentence1: Ndise oro ama afiak etie ntre ke isua ikie kiet ke ukperedem, ke ini mme Moors ẹkekotde un̄wam Almohads ke isua 1151.

sentence1: You can buy several of these to make your own line of narrow gables.
translatedsentence1: Afo ekeme ndidep ediwak ke otu mme emi man anam udu n̄kpọk fo eke n̄kpri n̄kpri.

sentence1: From May to mid-October, the Boston Harbor Cruise Company (Tel.
translatedsentence1: Tọn̄ọ ke May esịm ufọt October, Boston Harbor Cruise Company (Tel.

sentence1: The sea is reached only by narrow lanes and farm tracks, but it's worth a trek to get away from the crowds.
translatedsentence1: Inyan̄ esịne ke n̄kpri usụn̄ ye usụn̄ in̄wan̄ kpọt, edi enen̄ede ọfọn ndisan̄a n̄kpọn̄ mme owo.

sentence1: With reinforcements, the Spaniards managed to establish a beachhead.
translatedsentence1: Ke un̄wam ekọn̄, mbon Spain ẹma ẹkeme ndida ebiet ke mben inyan̄.

sentence1: Even so, Paris recently created miles of cycling lanes that crisscross the entire city, making bicycling much safer (and more popular).
translatedsentence1: Kpa ye oro, Paris ama anam ediwak ikpọ usụn keke emi ẹsan̄ade ẹbe ofụri obio, oro anamde ndida keke nsana eti-eti (ye oro ẹmade etieti ẹkan).

sentence1: You will find a pleasant beach nearby at Batu Hitam.
translatedsentence1: Afo eyekụt edịbe emem-emem ke n̄kpọk ke Batu Hitam.

sentence1: In horse-drawn carts you visit costumed villagers tilling and harvesting, sheep-shearing, grinding flour in the mill, weaving, and fashioning horseshoes in the smithy.
translatedsentence1: Ke ikpa-inyene enyọn̄, afo eyeda mme owo obio emi ẹdọn̄de ọfọn̄, ẹkọk, ẹnyụn̄ ẹtịbi, ẹnyụn̄ ẹkpa erọn̄, ẹnyụn̄ ẹtịbi ntụk ke ufọk-ntụk, ẹnyụn̄ ẹkpa ọfọn̄, ẹnyụn̄ ẹnam ikpa-ukot enyọn̄ ke ufọk-ibok.

sentence1: Smaller boats for local jaunts can be rented at Sea Horse Boat Rentals, Marsh Harbour, Abacos (Tel.
translatedsentence1: Ekpri ubom eke ndika n̄kpri isan̄ ke obio ẹkeme ndibọk ke Sea Horse Boat Rentals, Marsh Harbour, Abacos (Tel.

sentence1: The outrageous and conservative, one learns, coexist here without much fuss.
translatedsentence1: Owo ekpep ke mme n̄kpọ eke ẹtiede n̄kpọsọn̄ n̄kpọ ye mme n̄kpọ eke mînyeneke ndobo ẹdụn̄ ke ebiet emi kiet ke mînyeneke mfịna.

sentence1: The cross is said to weigh 181,740 tons.
translatedsentence1: Ẹdọhọ ke enyan̄a enyene ubom ton 181,740.

sentence1: The ruthless defense minister Gustav Noske called in 4,000 Freikorps (right-wing storm-troopers) to smash the movement.
translatedsentence1: Gustav Noske, emi ekedide etubom ukpeme obio emi mînyeneke mbom, okokot mbon Freikorps (nditọ-owo ukọk-ukọk) 4,000 ẹdi man ẹmenede ukpọk ukpọk ẹsịbe ukpọk ukpọk.

sentence1: Today, tour groups come for short stays and, as everywhere in Bali, standards and prices are steadily going up.
translatedsentence1: Mfịn, otu mbon isan̄-ukwọk ẹdi ẹdida ke ini ibio, ndien nte ke kpukpru ebiet ke Bali, n̄kpọsọn̄ ye okụk ẹka iso ẹnyọn̄ọ.

sentence1: It was they who made the first and hardiest effort to hew a modern living out of this hard land.
translatedsentence1: Mmọ ẹkedi mbon oro ẹkenamde akpa ye ọkpọsọn̄ ukeme ndida usụn̄ ndu uwem eke eyomfịn ke isọn̄ emi ọkpọsọn̄de.

sentence1: Built in a.d. 688-691, it is decorated in thousands of exquisite, predominantly blue and yellow, Persian ceramic tiles, with Koranic scriptures on the lintels.
translatedsentence1: Ẹkebọp enye ke isua 688-691 E.N., ẹdọn̄de enye ke tọsịn tọsịn n̄kpọ ndoho tile ceramic eke Persia, emi akam edide akpan akpan obubịt ye ofiom, ye ikọ Abasi Quran ke enyọn̄ usụn̄.

sentence1: Notice how the trompe l'oeil painting on the low arched ceiling aspires to turn the little church into a lofty Gothic cathedral.
translatedsentence1: Kop nte ndise oro ẹdade ẹda owo ke n̄kpọkpri enyọn̄ ufọkabasi oro ẹkọn̄de, oyom ndikabade ekpri ufọkabasi oro nte akwa ufọkabasi Gothic.

sentence1: Freshwater anglers must have a permit ask at the nearest tourist office for information on how to obtain one.
translatedsentence1: Mme andidaha ikpa-mmọn̄ ẹkpenyene n̄wed-ubọk. Bụp ke ufọk-utom mme isen-owo eke ekpere ndifiọk nte ẹkpedaha kiet.

sentence1: To see some of Cluny's impact on the surrounding countryside, visit a few of the villages whose Romanesque churches were built by Cluny's architects and  among them, Saint-Vincent-des-Pres, Taize, Berze-la-Ville, and Malay.
translatedsentence1: Man afo okụt ndusụk utịp Cluny ke ikpehe obio emi ekịmde, sika ndusụk obio-nkpri emi mme ufọkabasi mmọ eke Romanesque ẹkedade mme ọbọp-ufọk Cluny ẹbọp, ndien ke otu mmọ ẹdi Saint-Vincent-des-Pres, Taize, Berze-la-Ville, ye Malay.

sentence1: Only hikes accompanied by guides from the local guiding cooperative are advised.
translatedsentence1: Mme isan̄ ukwọrọikọ eke mme andikaisan̄ ke otu nka mme andikaisan̄ ukwọrọikọ kpọt ke ẹdori utịn̄ikọ.

sentence1: At the moment, the thinking is that it's perhaps best to leave these smaller, less developed islands in peace.
translatedsentence1: Ke ini emi, ekikere edi ke edi se ifon̄de akan ndikpọn̄ mme ekpri isuo emi, eke mîkọkọrike eti, ke emem.

sentence1: One inmate returning for the guided tour surprisingly, some do, out of nostalgia said the food was better than he had eaten in many San Francisco hotels.
translatedsentence1: Owo n̄kpọkọbi kiet emi akpade kaban̄a ndausung isan̄, ke n̄kpọ n̄kpaidem, ndusụk ẹsinam ntre, ke ntak editi n̄kpọ, ọkọdọhọ ke udia ama ọfọn akan se imọ ikadia ke ediwak ufọkibọk San Francisco.

sentence1: Even in these early times the gods would be consulted with the oracle issuing their verdicts from the Rock of Sybil.
translatedsentence1: Idem ke ini akpa emi, ẹkesibụp mme abasi, ndien ubọkn̄ka ẹkesinam ikpe mmọ ẹto Akpa Sybil.

sentence1: The Baixada de Santa Eulalia descends to carrer dels Banys Nous, named for the long-gone  new  baths of the ghetto erected in the 12th century.
translatedsentence1: Baixada de Santa Eulalia osụhọde aka carrer dels Banys Nous, emi ẹkekotde ke enyịn̄ mme ufọk-iyak obufa emi mîdụhe aba ke ghetto, emi ẹkebọpde ke ọyọhọ isua ikie duopeba.

sentence1: Once you're off the traffic-squeezed main arteries, you'll find that Albufeira's old town preserves a surprising bit of traditional charm.
translatedsentence1: Ke ini afo osioho ke akpan usung ubom emi ubom edemede, afo eyekut ke obio Albufeira owo ekpeme n̄kpọ emi akpa owo n̄kpoho ke ediye ido eke eset.

sentence1: Close to the original action and still providing the most vivid testimony to the Klondike days, the boomtown of Dawson City yielded in 1951 to the transportation and communications center of Whitehorse as territorial capital.
translatedsentence1: Enyịn ke akpa n̄kpọ oro eketịbede, ye edinyene ata akpan ntiense aban̄a ini Klondike, obio oro okokponide ke ukpọk-ukpọk, Dawson City, ọkọkpọn̄ itie ke 1951 ọnọ Whitehorse, kpa itie usuan̄kpọ ye n̄kpọ nsuan̄ikọ, nte akpan obio ikpehe isọn̄ oro.

sentence1: This was the island bought by Errol Flynn when he settled in Port Antonio in 1946
translatedsentence1: Emi ekedi isuo emi Errol Flynn okotde ke ini enye akada ke Port Antonio ke isua 1946

sentence1: Cala Mondrage is practically undeveloped (by the standards of coastal Mallorca), and may stay that way by order of the regional government, which has become alarmed by the specter of unchecked building along the coast.
translatedsentence1: Cala Mondrage ikpọkọke didie didie (ke usụn̄ emi mme owo ẹsinịmde ke ikpa inyan̄ Mallorca), ndien ekeme ndisụk n̄kpa ntre ke uyo ukara ikpehe oro, emi esịt akabade ofụhọde ke ntak n̄kpọndịk edidep ufọk ke ikpa inyan̄ ke usụn̄ emi mme owo mîkpemeke.

sentence1: It has three meru-topped shrines dedicated to Brahma, Shiva, and Vishnu.
translatedsentence1: Enye enyene mme ufọk-abasi ita eke enyenede ikpa-enyọn̄ meru eke ẹnọde Brahma, Shiva, ye Vishnu.

sentence1: Less than a mile past the Arboretum, you will find two churches on the right side of the road, backed by hundreds of white painted family tombs on the hillside.
translatedsentence1: Ke se ibede usụn̄ kilomita kiet ke edem Arboretum, afo oyomode ufọkabasi iba ke nnasia usụn̄, emi ẹnyenede ke edem edidịm n̄kpọkịbi ubon emi ẹyetde nsat ke obot.

sentence1: The Stampede was originally conceived to show all the techniques and excitement of rounding up cattle on the prairies.
translatedsentence1: Stampede oro ekedi akpa ekikere ndiwak kpukpru usung utom ye idatesit ndikop enan ke akamba ikot.

sentence1: Almost 100,000 people a day come here to marvel at the striking architecture and explore the latest attractions in this ever-changing city.
translatedsentence1: N̄kpọ nte owo 100,000 ke usen kiet ẹdi mi man ẹse ẹdara mme ufọk oro ẹdide n̄kpọ ndara, ye ndidụn̄ọde mme obufa n̄kpọ ndara ke obio emi esikpụhọrede kpukpru ini.

sentence1: The Beaux Arts City Hall has been replaced by nearby Government Center.
translatedsentence1: Ufok Ukara Obio Beaux Arts ama ebiere enyịn ke Ufok Ukara Obio emi ekpere.

sentence1: Behind the hotel, beyond an 1898 statue of Samuel de Champlain, the city's founder, Dufferin Terrace offers a magnificent view over the St. Lawrence and downriver to the Ile d'Orleans.
translatedsentence1: Ke edem ufọk-edia, ebre ndisana ikpoto Samuel de Champlain eke isua 1898, owo emi okobotde obio, Dufferin Terrace oworo eti nte enye esede ke enyọn̄ Akpa St. Lawrence ye ke idak akpa tutu esịm Ile d'Orleans.

sentence1: Beyond Payangan, the little-used road wends its way through scenic countryside all the way to Batur (see pagea59).
translatedsentence1: Ke edem Payangan, usụn̄ oro mîsịneke ukpọk-ukpọk ebịne ke n̄kann̄kụk obio emi enyenede n̄kpọ ndise tutu esịm Batur (se pagea59).

sentence1: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), founded in 1861 is America's leading science and engineering establishment that has pioneered many modern technologies, from stroboscopic photography to food preservation processes.
translatedsentence1: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), emi ẹkewụkde ke 1861, edi akpan ufọkn̄wed sayensị ye injinia America emi ẹketọn̄ọde ediwak obufa mme n̄kpọuto, ọtọn̄ọde ke ndise stroboscopic esịmde usụn̄ ndikpeme n̄kpọudia.

sentence1: Six kilometers (4 miles) north of Ipoh is the Perak Tong, built in 1926 by a Buddhist priest from China.
translatedsentence1: Kilomita itiaba (mile inan) ke edere-edem Ipoh edi Perak Tong, emi owo ufọkabasi Buddha emi otode China ekebọpde ke isua 1926.

sentence1: Kodaly kerend (Kodaly crescent, named after another Hungarian composer) is a splendid ensemble, its curving faaades decorated with Classical  gures and inlaid motifs.
translatedsentence1: Kodaly kerend (Kodaly crescent, emi ẹkenịmde enyịn̄ ke akpan akpan ke ekebe efen eke Hungary) edi akwa otu, ye mme enyịn̄ enyịn̄ esie emi ẹkpọn̄de, emi ẹdọn̄de mme ndise Classical ye mme ndise emi ẹdọn̄de ke ikpọk.

sentence1: Plans to house parliament here after Independence came to nothing
translatedsentence1: Nkpana ndida ufok nnọ esop andikara mi ke ama akakabade obio idaha ikabadeke n̄kpọ.

sentence1: Examples of every locally produced craft can be found in abundance here, and you'll shop cheaper than in the resorts, especially if you practice your bartering skills beforehand.
translatedsentence1: N̄kpọ ndida n̄wụk ke kpukpru n̄kpọ emi ẹnamde ke obio do ẹdu ke ediwak itie mi, ndien afo oyom n̄kpọ ke ikpọho n̄kpọ akan ke mme ebiet emi mme owo ẹdụn̄de, akpan akpan edieke afo anamde n̄kpọ ndinyene ifiọk ndinyam n̄kpọ ke ikpọho n̄kpọ mbemiso.

sentence1: The 60-year rule of Ramses II (1279-1212 b.c. ) was a great finale to the New Kingdom era.
translatedsentence1: Ikan̄n̄a isua 60 eke Ramses II (1279-1212 b.c.) ekedi akwa utịt ke ini Obio Obufa.

sentence1: From the air you'll be able to see that Sarawak boasts the country's longest river, the Rejang, flowing 563 km (351 miles) from the mountains on the Indonesian border to the South China Sea.
translatedsentence1: Ke enyọn̄, afo eyekeme ndikụt ke Sarawak enyene akwa akpa isọn̄ oro, Rejang, oro asan̄ade kilomita 563 (mile 351) oto ke ikpọ obot ke adianade ye Indonesia esịm Inyan̄ China Enyọn̄.

sentence1: An entrance tunnel with a kitchen alcove on one side, and storage alcoves on the other, leads to the main living area.
translatedsentence1: Usung-udong unyọn̄ emi enyenede ufok-udia ekpri ke n̄kan̄ kiet, ye mme ebiet-edịbe ekpri ke n̄kan̄ efen, ada esịm akpan ebiet-idụn̄.

sentence1: The National Theater and Concert Hall, Tel. 01-7282333, more commonly known as the Megaron, is situated on Vas.
translatedsentence1: Ufok Ukpep Ikwo ye Ufok Nditop Ikwo Eka Obio, Nọmba fon: 01-7282333, emi ẹdiọn̄ọde nte Megaron, odude ke Vas.

sentence1: Although it helps if you have an interest in American politics, the displays allowing you to listen to a Watergate tape or  interview  Nixon on foreign affairs are nevertheless interesting.
translatedsentence1: Kpa ye nte ke an̄wam edieke afo enyenede udorien̄wan̄ ke n̄kpọ ukara America, mme n̄kpọ oro ẹwụtde oro ẹyakde afo akpan̄ utọn̄ ke kaset Watergate m̀mê neme nneme ye Nixon aban̄a n̄kpọ an̄wa idụt ẹsụk ẹnyene udorien̄wan̄.

sentence1: The town's other great Roman monument, the theatre antique, is on the south side of town.
translatedsentence1: N̄kpọ n̄kpọsọn̄ Rome efen oro akwa ke obio oro, kpa "theatre antique" oro, odu ke ikpa-edem usụk obio.

sentence1: The building constructed above the underground quarters of the SS guards houses the Topographie des Terrors, an exhibition of photographs and documents which movingly illustrates the lives of those who resisted the Nazi terror.
translatedsentence1: Obio-ufok oro ẹkebọpde ke enyọn̄ ebiet idak isọn̄ mbon ukpeme SS enyene Topographie des Terrors, kpa n̄kpọ ndiwụt ndise ye n̄wed emi owụtde ke usụn̄ oro otụkde owo uwem mbon oro ẹkebiomde ndịk Nazi.

sentence1: If and when that project is completed, it should become one of the most interesting of the entire chain.
translatedsentence1: Edieke ye ini eke utom oro ama okure, ana enye akabade edi kiet ke otu mme n̄kpọ eke enyenede udori ye inemesit akan ke ofụri usụn̄.

sentence1: The hand-made cars are the city's best-loved attraction, and the system was declared a National Historic Landmark in 1964.
translatedsentence1: Mme ubom oro ẹkewetde ke ubọk edi n̄kpọ oro mme owo ẹmade etieti ke obio, ndien ẹkenam n̄kpọ emi edi N̄kpọ Akpan Nneme Obio ke 1964.

sentence1: During the Depression, it was the country's poorest province, close to starvation.
translatedsentence1: Ke ini ukụt, enye ekedi obio-ukara emi mînyeneke n̄kpọ akan ke idụt, ekpere ndikpa-ukụt.

sentence1: The 1992 Olympics cemented Barcelona's reputation as a sports-mad city.
translatedsentence1: Efesịm Olympics eke 1992 ama anam enyịn̄ Barcelona ọsọn̄ ubọk nte obio oro amade mbre etieti.

sentence1: Wander the decks and talk to the actors who play the parts of sailors and pilgrims.
translatedsentence1: San̄a ke mme ubom, nyụn̄ neme ye mme odomo ndise emi ẹdomode ndise mme akwa ubom ye mme isan̄.

sentence1: The building's most legendary feature is the grasshopper weathervane.
translatedsentence1: Akpan n̄kpọ oro ẹtịn̄de etop etieti ke ufọk oro edi uduenek n̄kpọ ofụm.

sentence1: For longer stays, the information office provides detailed maps of Quetico's fantastic network of interlocking waterways.
translatedsentence1: Mme owo emi edidụn̄de anyan ini, ufọk n̄wed n̄kpọntịbe ọnọ mmọ anyan n̄wed ndise obio Quetico emi enyenede n̄kpọsọn̄ usụn̄ mmọn̄ emi ẹdianade kiet.

sentence1: Pei tower a winding path leads up to Hong Kong Park.
translatedsentence1: Usụn̄ oro abiatde oto Pei tower ada okpoho Hong Kong Park.

sentence1: The chairlift is a great favourite.
translatedsentence1: N̄kpọkụbọk emi esimen owo ke enyọn̄ edi se mme owo ẹmade etieti.

sentence1: For information, call (213) 623-2489 on weekdays between 9am and 5pm.
translatedsentence1: Mban̄a nneme, kot (213) 623-2489 ke usenutom ke ufọt n̄kanika 9 usenubọk ye n̄kanika 5 mbubịteyo.

sentence1: The island's tranquility lasted until 1287, when Alfonso III of Aragen, smarting over a series of humiliations at the hands of his nobles, found a pretext for invasion.
translatedsentence1: Emem isuo oro okodu tutu isua 1287, ke ini Alfonso III eke Aragen, emi okosụk etie ke ubiak ke ntak ediwak esuene emi mme akwa owo esie ẹkenamde enye, okokụt ntak ndida n̄kanade.

sentence1: On a platform above the columns is a carved figure of Chaac-Mool in reclining position, its belly hollowed into a bowl to receive offerings some experts think these included human hearts fresh from the body.
translatedsentence1: Ke enyọn̄ ubọk ke enyọn̄ ikpan̄, ndise Chaac-Mool emi ẹkọkde ke usụn̄ idap odu, esịt esie ẹkọk ke obube man ẹbọ uwa; ndusụk mme ọfiọk ẹkere ke mme uwa emi ẹkesịne esịt owo emi ẹkpụhọrede ke idem.

sentence1: The largest town on the lake's south coast is Siefok.
translatedsentence1: Akwa obio ke ikpa isuo inyan̄ ke usuk edi Siefok.

sentence1: From a Gothic portico in the middle of town, beside the massive 13th-acentury campanile, a staircase of 90 steps takes you down to the sanctuary's 11th-century bronze doors.

sentence1: They love to socialize, and bars particularly the famous  brown bars  are the place where they meet, usually to put the world to rights.

sentence1: The Liao capital at Beijing, then known as Yanjing, occupied the southeast region of what is the modern capital today, with the Fayuan Temple the only surviving monument.

sentence1: On your way, you'll pass the Palace of Fine Arts, a restored relic of the Panama-Pacific International Exposition.

sentence1: As it snakes up and down the peaks and ridges, the wall conforms to a challenging topography, one that leaves many tourists gasping for breath.

sentence1: The intricacies of the Gallic subjunctive do not worry him at all, and for the best reason in the  he does not even bother to try.
translatedsentence1: Mme mfịna usụn̄ ikọ subjunctive mbon Gallic ifịnake enye esịt baba esisịt, ndien ke ntak oro ọfọnde akan, enye idomoke ndin̄wana.

sentence1: But he would indeed be feigning naavete to claim that generic man is now understood to include woman.
translatedsentence1: Edi enye akpakam edisuene idem ke mfịna ndidọhọ ke ẹda owo ke ofụri esie idahaemi nte enye esịne n̄wan.

sentence1: As Welsh's book has a list under PRONUNCIATION, I looked there, to no avail.
translatedsentence1: Nte n̄wed Welsh enyenede ndido ke idak N̄kpōn̄-ikọ, n̄kese do, edi akanam n̄kpọ.

sentence1: In the same way, manual typewriters depend on the full force of the fingers to create words, rather than on electric (or electronic) assistance.
translatedsentence1: Kpa nte ntre, mme n̄wedndọhọ-ubọk ẹberede edem ke ofụri odudu mme nnuenubọk ndida n̄wet ikọ, utu ke un̄wam ikan̄ ilektrik (m̀mê electronic).

sentence1: It seems silly to separate Gruyare the cheese from Gruyare the place in Switzerland whence it comes' indeed, the latter is not even an entry in the geographical sections of either dictionary.
translatedsentence1: Etie nte ndisịme n̄kpọ ndibahade cheese Gruyare ye obio Gruyare ke Switzerland emi enye otode, ke akpanikọ, enyịn̄ obio emi idụhe kan̄a ke ikpehe mbụk isọn̄ ke dictionary mbiba.

sentence1: See that curious little beast over there?
translatedsentence1: Se ekpri n̄kpọ-idem unam ọkọ do?

sentence1: I derive enormous enjoyment from reading through back issues of such periodicals, a rather formidable prospect when you consider that each year makes up two volumes of about 400-odd pages each.
translatedsentence1: Esịt enem mi etieti ndikot mme n̄kani n̄wed mbụk utọ oro, emi edide ata akamba utom ke ini ekerede ete ke kpukpru isua ẹnyene n̄wed iba emi kiet kiet enyenede n̄kpọ nte page 400.

sentence1: That Swede church  isn't quite the same as  That Swedish church.
translatedsentence1: Ufọk Abasi owo Sweden oro idịghe ukem ukem nte Ufọk Abasi mbon Sweden oro.

sentence1: I was raised (Southern for being brought up by one's parents) where the train station, or depot, was the DEE-po.
translatedsentence1: Ke ebiet emi n̄kọkọride, ikesikot ufọk-ukop-isọn̄, m̀mê depot, DEE-po.

sentence1: No one seems to know if these sports are played on a court with a net, against a wall, or both.
translatedsentence1: Etie nte owo ndomokiet ifiọkke m̀mê ẹbre mme mbre emi ke an̄wa emi enyenede ubọk, ẹbre ye ibibene, m̀mê mbiba.

sentence1: One difference is that other groups need to do so because in order to function they must either attach new meanings to existing words and phrases or coin new words and pharases.
translatedsentence1: Nsio nsio kiet edi nte ke mme otu eken ẹnyene ndinam ntre koro man ẹkeme ndinam utom, ana mmọ ẹsịn obufa itieutom ke mme ikọ ye ufan̄ikọ eke ẹdude m̀mê ẹbot mbufa ikọ ye ufan̄ikọ.

sentence1: Some American place names have a unique resonance about them--places like Maggie's Nipples, Wyoming, or Greasy Creek, Arkansas, Lickskillet, Kentucky, or Scroungeout, Alabama.
translatedsentence1: Ndusụk en̄yịn̄ itie ke America enyene n̄kpọ eke anamde enye edi isio isio—utie nte Maggie's Nipples, ke Wyoming, m̀mê Greasy Creek, ke Arkansas, Lickskillet, ke Kentucky, m̀mê Scroungeout, ke Alabama.

sentence1: Despite their reputation for distrusting polyglots, it is by no means unusual for Englishmen to be bilingual.
translatedsentence1: Okposụkedi nte ẹsiwakde nditịn̄ ke mbon England inyeneke mbuọtidem ke mbon oro ẹsemde ediwak usem, idịghe n̄kpọ esen ndikụt mmọ ẹsemde usem iba.

sentence1: Thus, once a pleasing motif has been discovered, the next least exerting is to reproduce it with a slight variation.
translatedsentence1: Ntem, ke ini ẹkụtde uwem n̄kpọ oro enemde esịt, n̄kpọ efen oro mîsọn̄ke utom edi ndifiak nnam enye ye esisịt ukpụhọde.

sentence1: The Auld Alliance, a treaty of accord between France and Scotland, was born.
translatedsentence1: Auld Alliance, ediomi un̄wana ke ufọt France ye Scotland, ama amana.

sentence1: This is not to say that the Western tradition has a monopoly on Niceness.
translatedsentence1: Emi idọhọke ite ke ido mbon Edem Usoputịn ẹnyene eti ido ke idem ikpọn̄.

sentence1: Banquet is not nearly parquet,
translatedsentence1: Udia usọrọ idịghe n̄kpọ kiet ye paket.

sentence1: The major Italian guidebook to Rome soberly claims that this building has been nicknamed Il Colosseo Quadrato , `The Square Colosseum.
translatedsentence1: Akpan n̄wed ndūnānam mbon Italy emi aban̄ade Rome ọdọhọ ye ifiọk ete ke ẹkot ufọk emi enyịn̄ mbubru Il Colosseo Quadrato, `Colosseum Inan̄-mbiet.`

sentence1: Caller says,  Thank you for taking my call.
translatedsentence1: Sosongo ke ndibọrọ ikot mi.

sentence1: Its precursor was the now quite obsolete strangury (1398) `slow and painful urination.
translatedsentence1: Mbemiso esie ekedi ikọ emi ẹkotde strangury (1398) emi mîdụhe aba ke usụn̄, `editịm ikịm sụn̄sụn̄ ye ubiak ubiak.

sentence1: Via di Ripetta imperceptibly merges into Via della Scrofa `Street of the Sow,' named after another ancient sculpture that is still preserved there.
translatedsentence1: Via di Ripetta akabade sụn̄sụn̄ odụk Via della Scrofa `Ufọk Eke,' emi ẹkesiode enyịn̄ ẹto mbiet eset en̄wen emi osụk odude do tutu emi.

sentence1: And rest easy, Miss Dalrymple, when I reedit speech scripts for print publication, I always revert to good old academically pure English usage.
translatedsentence1: Ndien kûfịghe, Ọbọñwa Dalrymple, ke ini nfiakde ndọhọ mme n̄wed ukọikọ nnọ edimịn̄, nsinsi mfiak nnyọn̄ọ ke edima asan̄ade-asan̄a Ikọmbakara eke n̄wed.

sentence1: There is a linguistic process in the evolution of our vocabulary that is not functioning with a high rate of efficiency.
translatedsentence1: Odu usụn̄ usem kiet ke n̄kọri ikọ nnyịn emi mînamke utom ke ọkpọsọn̄ udom.

sentence1: A number of them might have been created by prisoners whose vocabularies were too small to accommodate the concepts, events, or situations named.
translatedsentence1: Ekeme ndidi mbon n̄kpọkọbi ẹkenam ndusụk mmọ, emi odudu ikọ mmọ ekekpri akaha ndida nnịm ekikere, mme n̄kpọntịbe, m̀mê idaha eke ẹsiakde enyịn̄.

sentence1: Inglish differs from English in five  words, expressions, grammar, pronunciation and rhythm.
translatedsentence1: Inglish okpụhọde ye Ikọmbakara ke n̄kpọ ition: mme ikọ, mme usem ikọ, grammar, pronunciation ye rhythm.

sentence1: One must be very cautious in proposing etymologies that attribute the origin of a word to playfulness or  they often turn out to be folk etymologies and totally empty of anything more than hollow speculation.
translatedsentence1: Ana owo enyene ntiense etieti ke ndinọ mme ntak ntọn̄ọ ikọ emi ẹdọhọde ke ikọ oto ke mbre, koro ediwak ini mmọ ẹsikabade ẹdi ntak-ikọ mbon owo, ẹnyụn̄ ẹdi ikpîkpu, inyeneke n̄kpọ ndomokiet ke esịt ke mîbọhọke ekikere efu.

sentence1: Davidson should not adopt the pronunciation of scone to rhyme with `bone'--at any rate not because Victoria, where he lives, is  veddy English.
translatedsentence1: Davidson ikpaha ndikpebe n̄te ẹsiakotde scone man etie nte 'bone'—ke usụn̄ ekededi, idịghe koro Victoria, emi enye odụn̄de, edi ata n̄kpọ mbon English.

sentence1: The average novel of 200,000 words for $25 works out at 8,000 words per dollar.
translatedsentence1: N̄wed mbụk emi enyenede ikọ 200,000 ke dollar 25 ọwọrọ ikọ 8,000 ke dollar kiet.
